@Pooyahat I do try to answer these emails, but it's basically with information that they could have gotten from the web, since I cannot read their application specifically. If I was 100% sure that I will *not* be taking any students then I could say that, but that's never the case.

@Pooyahat We do have a very smooth application fee waiver program https://t.co/5LjyTRsqks  but regardless I cannot read and evaluate an email whether an application will be successful.

@jasondhartline Harvard has a very smooth application fee waiver process https://t.co/5LjyTRbnis  but in any case, I simply cannot evaluate applications until the period of time which I dedicate to it.

Teaching in AddisCoder and JamCoders has been an amazing experience, and I cannot overstate these programs' impact. 

I once met an AddisCoder graduate at a reception for @minilek's wedding. I asked him whether he enjoyed the course. He said, "Enjoyed it? It was life-changing!" https://t.co/lEHER27e73

The short answer is don't.

@Ozan__Caglayan If you want to start a movement to drop this term, go ahead, but this is not a battle to take on the back of the unlucky authors that got you as a reviewer.
@PradyuPrasad Don't give up! Elon can still make it up...

@UdiWieder @CSProfKGD Not taking a position on this debate, but it is at least held in the right way - public forums and not anonymous reviews. Also, the aim is to convince people to adopt a new term for a relatively recent concept, rather than reject papers who use the other term.
@UdiWieder @CSProfKGD https://t.co/Fnkg46tjV1 and https://t.co/O4lgUQCNMc

@CSProfKGD In contrast here the reviewer took a term that has been used for 40 years, and for which there was never a public outcry over, and decided that the context of a review in ICLR for one particular paper is the right place to have this fight. I think this reviewer is just a troll.

@CSProfKGD Consdier  "quantum supremacy". It has been in use far shorter time than "byzantine agreement". Some people have found it offensive and made a public campaign to use "quantum advantage" instead. Many authors listened, but the term is still used, and is not ground for rejection.

"Byzantine agreement" has been a technical term for 40+ years, used in tens of thousands of papers. Still, if there was a grassroots movement of people identifying as byzantine who find it offensive, they should be heard. 

But it's not up to an ICLR reviewer to make such demand. https://t.co/PEj93AmKPk

7/7 The obvious response is why not just optimize the real measure and not the proxy one, but this is generally impossible since we usually can't translate what we care about into a single number, and definitely not one that we can measure.

6/7 Algorithmic systems are a "double edged sword" in that they can optimize very quickly and so are very "efficient" in optimizing whatever proxy measure they are aiming for. We've already seen this in the 2010 "Flash Crash" and it's likely to happen more.

5/7 In human / social system we often add regulations as "regularizations" - ways to inject inefficiencies into the system so as to prevent over optimization. E.g., rent control stops converting all apartments into luxury ones in boom times, which will then be empty in recessions

4/7 In fact, just this Friday @johnschulman2 gave a talk in our seminar about "over optimization" to a proxy reward model in the context of training language models to follow instructions. https://t.co/aDA2PRHCPO

3/7 this should not detract from the general point, that in many cases, as a system, whether algorithmic, individual, or societal, becomes too efficient at optimizing its proxy measure, it starts growing further away from the true goals we care about in the first place.

2/7 The strong version is that at some point optimizing P will become *negatively* correlated with O. In machine learning we call this "over fitting". There are special (but important!) cases where over-fitting is benign, as in @jaschad's plot or https://t.co/koQLtCpHVv but ..

Great post! My thoughts below:

Goodhart's law is "when a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure"
Mathematically,  for any objective O and proxy measure P for O, if we optimize P maximally then at some point it will no longer be positively correlated with O. 1/7 https://t.co/gIjUI3CfNa

@CRSegerie A big difference with Go/Chess is that math doesn't have artificial rules, which prevent humans from working together with AIs, and also make for strict measurable metrics. In math inventing/discovering the questions to be solved is a large part of the sources.
@gershbrain It seems that often new engineering ideas come less from thinking about the structure of the problem, and more from thinking about the structure of the hardware that we have to work with.

in the sense that AI systems are becoming less problem-specific, and it does seem that the underlying representations they learn have similarities to those learned by natural NNs.

Less about copying an activation function from the brain, and more about understanding processes

Good thread. Predictions are famously very hard, especially about the future, which is also why we can't infer the usefulness of a field for the future of AI from the past.
